newsitem.title: LATVIA: Latvia turns back clocks alone, angers airlines.
newsitem.headline: Latvia turns back clocks alone, angers airlines.

text.p: International airlines in the Baltic state of Latvia were angry on Monday after the country turned back its clocks by an hour, one month ahead of the rest of Europe and neighbours Lithuania and Estonia.

Airlines were only informed of the change near the end of last week and were forced to take out last-minute newspaper, television and radio advertisements to warn their customers, local Finnair general manager Kari Stolbov told Reuters.
"All airlines are sort of shocked by this thing," he said.
The clocks went back to winter time, GMT plus two hours, during the early hours of September 29 -- following the old timetable of the former Soviet Union.
A government spokesman said Latvia was out of step after officials failed to present the legislation needed to enforce a new time change in time for the cabinet to approve it.
The rest of Europe is to move to winter time at the end of October and Lithuania and Estonia plan to follow suit.

"Not only us but practically all organisations including IATA (the International Air Transport Association) were informed by government bodies that the change would take place at the end of October," said Oleg Korshe, spokesman for Air Baltic, part-owned by Scandinavian Airlines.
